title: Living trust from now deceased parents, 2 daughters beneficiaries 50-50, no problems...
question: the 2 children both in 60's single, no children, inheirited 50 50 a pd in full home they reside in, time share some cash all placed in the trust account name, both had credit debt issues supposedly being handled as negotiations opposed to bankruptcy in order to not lose parents assets, can a card company or their collector place lien on the home, bank accounts whatever which are under the trust? 1 recently got served with papers just dropped at front door,...was under assumption attorney had been working on all accounts last few yrs so a total shock..can home be taken? can a bankruptcy cause more issues? with much thanx from 2 very worried siblings
answers: You two have far too many concerns to be able to have everything addressed in this forum. The other attorneys here have give you some solid advice. I would recommend that you speak with a Riverside County attorney asap and do not delay. Contact Stuart Steingraber as I believe he covers Palm Springs.
You need to talk to a bankruptcy lawyer about your options because your house could be in play. Too many variables here to give you a definite answer.

There are too many "moving parts" in your situation to give you useful advice. Best idea is to find/consult/hire a lawyer using the Avvo feature "Find a Lawyer". Make a list of 4-5 having many 5 star reviews from satisfied clients. If you don't get a prompt call back from one, go on to the next on your list. Some of us offer a free consultation by phone or in person. Take us up on it. Because the bankruptcy process can be handled entirely by phone, email and fax, there is no need to personally visit the lawyer’s office unless you want to. Don’t be limited by the location of the BK lawyers you select.

That said, here are some of the issues to be resolved: Value of the real estate; amount of debt you owe; are you both debtors on the same accounts or do you each owe separate and different debts? You will have to disclose the details of your "inheritance" via the trust to the bankruptcy trustee. Which type of BK works best for you: Chapter 7 or 13? Whatever you do, get an experienced BK lawyer to review your case. Remember, BK is more than checking boxes on forms you find online.

I changed this to Bankruptcy. You should see a bankruptcy attorney.
Just dropping the papers on the front door is not service UNLESS you were. home AND you were avoiding service. If they do that, they need to mail a copy of the summons and lawsuit to you.
Do not ignore the lawsuit. You need to 1 file a response (answer, demurrer or motion to strike), 2 file a motion to quash service of process, or 3 file bankruptcy.
